biogHists.text:
WHYY first began radio broadcasting in 1954 and soon expanded to include entertainment, educational, cultural,and news television broacasts. WHYY offices in Philadelphia, Pa. and Wilmington, Delaware provide programming for southeastern Pennsylvania, Delaware and South Jersey.

From the description of WHYY War Letters collection , 1861-1972. (Historical Society of Pennsylvania). WorldCat record id: 214330910

                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/cre">Creator</roleTerm>
                     </role>

                     <namePart>WHYY (Television station : Philadelphia, Pa.)</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/cre">Creator</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
                  <titleInfo>
                     <title>Papers. 1960-1987.</title>
                  </titleInfo>
                  <abstract>Collection documents Karayn's career in educational and public broadcasting through his work at National Educational Television, National Public Affairs Center for Television, the Greater Washington Educational Telecommunications Association, the League of Women Voters, WHYY, and Karayn and Company, Inc. </abstract>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>University of Maryland Libraries</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/rps">Repository</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
               </mods>
            </objectXMLWrap>

resource.abstract: Collection documents Karayn's career in educational and public broadcasting through his work at National Educational Television, National Public Affairs Center for Television, the Greater Washington Educational Telecommunications Association, the League of Women Voters, WHYY, and Karayn and Company, Inc.

resource.source:
<objectXMLWrap>
               <mods xmlns="http://www.loc.gov/mods/v3">
                  <recordInfo>
                     <recordOrigin>WorldCat:214330910</recordOrigin>
                     <recordContentSource>ISIL:OCLC-QQR</recordContentSource>
                  </recordInfo>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>WHYY (Television station : Philadelphia, Pa.)</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/cre">Creator</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
                  <titleInfo>
                     <title>WHYY War Letters collection , 1861-1972.</title>
                  </titleInfo>
                  <abstract>The collection consists of photocopies of about 2,000 letters given to WHYY for their War Letters Project, which explored the effects of war on humanity through first-hand accounts from soldiers on the battlefront to individuals on the homefront.   They span from the Civil War period (1860s) to the Vietnam era (1970s) and were donated primarily by members of WHYY's viewing audience. </abstract>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Historical Society of Pennsylvania</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/rps">Repository</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
               </mods>
            </objectXMLWrap>
resource.title: WHYY War Letters collection , 1861-1972.
resource.abstract: The collection consists of photocopies of about 2,000 letters given to WHYY for their War Letters Project, which explored the effects of war on humanity through first-hand accounts from soldiers on the battlefront to individuals on the homefront.   They span from the Civil War period (1860s) to the Vietnam era (1970s) and were donated primarily by members of WHYY's viewing audience.
resource.displayEntry: WHYY (Television station : Philadelphia, Pa.). WHYY War Letters collection , 1861-1972.

resource.source:
<objectXMLWrap>
               <mods xmlns="http://www.loc.gov/mods/v3">
                  <recordInfo>
                     <recordOrigin>WorldCat:84429849</recordOrigin>
                     <recordContentSource>ISIL:OCLC-DEH</recordContentSource>
                  </recordInfo>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Pew, J. Howard (John Howard), 1882-1971.</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/cre">Creator</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
                  <titleInfo>
                     <title>Files on the Pew Memorial Foundation, 1948-1957.</title>
                  </titleInfo>
                  <abstract>Most of the correspondents are grant-seeking individuals and institutions.  They include national and international conservative and religious organizations as well as Philadelphia-based cultural institutions.  J. Howard Pew considers grants to prevent the communist infiltration of the Boy and Girl Scouts of America.  In correspondence with George Wharton Pepper he ponders a donation to the Washington Cathedral.  Congressman Walter Henry Judd sends Pew reports on the persecution of Chinese intellectuals in Hong Kong, Macao, and Tawain.  In correspondence with several individuals Pew follows the University of Pennsylvania's University Museum of Archaeology and Anthropology's foundation-supported excavation of Biblical sites in the Middle East.  Notable correspondents include C. Everett Koop, Norman Vincent Peale, and Herbert Hoover.  (Correspndence is brief.)  Also contains letters congratulating Pew for starting the Pew Memorial Foundation. </abstract>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Hagley Museum & Library</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/rps">Repository</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
               </mods>
            </objectXMLWrap>
resource.title: Files on the Pew Memorial Foundation, 1948-1957.
resource.abstract: Most of the correspondents are grant-seeking individuals and institutions.  They include national and international conservative and religious organizations as well as Philadelphia-based cultural institutions.  J. Howard Pew considers grants to prevent the communist infiltration of the Boy and Girl Scouts of America.  In correspondence with George Wharton Pepper he ponders a donation to the Washington Cathedral.  Congressman Walter Henry Judd sends Pew reports on the persecution of Chinese intellectuals in Hong Kong, Macao, and Tawain.  In correspondence with several individuals Pew follows the University of Pennsylvania's University Museum of Archaeology and Anthropology's foundation-supported excavation of Biblical sites in the Middle East.  Notable correspondents include C. Everett Koop, Norman Vincent Peale, and Herbert Hoover.  (Correspndence is brief.)  Also contains letters congratulating Pew for starting the Pew Memorial Foundation.
resource.displayEntry: Pew, J. Howard (John Howard), 1882-1971. Files on the Pew Memorial Foundation, 1948-1957.

resourceRelations.content: Pew, J. Howard (John Howard), 1882-1971. Files on the Pew Memorial Foundation, 1948-1957.

                  </titleInfo>

Kraetzer, Jim Karayn, and Roger Hall, including proposals for television programs of the Philadelphia Orchestra and items from Ormandy or his representative. </abstract>

resource.source:
<objectXMLWrap>
               <did xmlns="urn:isbn:1-931666-22-9">
                  <unittitle>R. Buckminster Fuller papers</unittitle>
                  <unitdate>ca. 1920-1983</unitdate>
                  <unitid>M1090</unitid>
                  <origination>
                     <persname>Fuller, R. Buckminster (Richard Buckminster), 1895-1983</persname>
                  </origination>
                  <physdesc>
                     <extent>1200 linear ft.</extent>
                  </physdesc>
                  <repository>
                     <corpname>Stanford University. Libraries. Dept. of Special Collections and University Archives.</corpname>
                  </repository>
                  <abstract>The papers of this 20th century polymath contain his personal archive the Dymaxion Chronofile, manuscripts, drawings and audio-visual materials relating to his career as an architect, mathematician, inventor and social critic.</abstract>
                  <langmaterial>
Languages represented in the collection: 
<language>English</language>
                  </langmaterial>
               </did>
            </objectXMLWrap>
resource.title: R. Buckminster Fuller papers ca. 1920-1983
resource.abstract: The papers of this 20th century polymath contain his personal archive the Dymaxion Chronofile, manuscripts, drawings and audio-visual materials relating to his career as an architect, mathematician, inventor and social critic.

resource.source:
<objectXMLWrap>
               <mods xmlns="http://www.loc.gov/mods/v3">
                  <recordInfo>
                     <recordOrigin>WorldCat:80027069</recordOrigin>
                     <recordContentSource>ISIL:OCLC-DEH</recordContentSource>
                  </recordInfo>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Pew Charitable Trusts.</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/cre">Creator</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
                  <titleInfo>
                     <title>Grant products reports, 1988-2002.</title>
                  </titleInfo>
                  <abstract>This series consists of both published and unpublished documents that constituted the final report or product of grants made by The Pew Charitable Trusts, the copies being submitted by the grant recipients. They document the scope of Pew's grant-making activities from 1988 to 2002. All program areas are represented, including: conservation and the environment, culture, education, health and human services, public policy, and religion. </abstract>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Hagley Museum & Library</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/rps">Repository</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
               </mods>
            </objectXMLWrap>
resource.title: Grant products reports, 1988-2002.
